content: The "Family Building Act of 2007" acknowledges infertility as a disease affecting millions of Americans and highlights the lack of coverage for infertility therapy in group health plans. The Act aims to establish standards for benefits related to the treatment of infertility. The "Family Building Act of 2007" aims to establish standards for benefits related to the treatment of infertility. The "Family Building Act of 2007" requires group health plans and health insurance issuers to cover treatment of infertility, defining infertility as the inability to conceive after 1 year of unprotected intercourse or carry a pregnancy to live birth. The "Family Building Act of 2007" mandates group health plans and health insurance issuers to cover infertility treatment, including various procedures like ovulation induction, artificial insemination, and in vitro fertilization, deemed non-experimental by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The "Family Building Act of 2007" requires health plans to cover infertility treatments, including assisted reproductive technology under certain conditions set by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. The "Family Building Act of 2007" mandates health plans to cover infertility treatments, including assisted reproductive technology, with specific conditions such as a lifetime cap of 6 oocyte retrievals at a qualified medical facility meeting certain standards. Assisted Reproductive Technology (ART) involves procedures with human egg and sperm to help women become pregnant. Types include in vitro fertilization, gamete intrafallopian transfer, embryo cryopreservation, and surrogate birth. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will review infertility treatment requirements within 5 years of the Family Building Act of 2007. The Family Building Act of 2007 addresses infertility treatment requirements for group health plans and health insurance coverage. It prohibits imposing excessive deductibles, coinsurance, or limitations on infertility therapy. Additionally, it prohibits denying eligibility based on infertility treatment and providing incentives to discourage infertility treatments. The Family Building Act of 2007 prohibits providers from withholding infertility treatments from qualified participants or beneficiaries, discussing treatment options, or penalizing providers for offering such treatments. It also clarifies that participants are not required to undergo infertility therapy. The Family Building Act of 2007 prohibits providers from withholding infertility treatments, allows negotiation of reimbursement levels, and does not preempt state laws providing greater benefits for infertility treatments. Effective dates for group health plans and insurance coverage are specified in the amendments, with exceptions for plans under collective bargaining agreements. The text chunk discusses the effective dates for plan years under collective bargaining agreements, specifying that the plan years begin before the termination of the agreements or 6 months after the enactment of the Act. Amendments made to conform to new requirements do not constitute a termination of the agreements. Section 3 of the Act amends Title 5, United States Code to require contracts providing obstetrical benefits to also cover infertility diagnosis and treatment. This amendment applies to contracts entered into or renewed at least 6 months after the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. DEFENSE HEALTH CARE PLANS. This section amends Chapter 55 of title 10 to require health care plans providing obstetrical benefits to also cover infertility diagnosis and treatment. The Secretary of Defense will prescribe necessary regulations for implementation. The amendment requires health care plans to cover infertility benefits, effective for contracts renewed at least 6 months after the enactment of the Act.
